metadata.title: The Transformation of the Canadian Domestic Servant, 1871-1931

relevance.topic: Labor displacement due to technological change
relevance.relevance: The study examines the decline of domestic service as a paid occupation and its replacement by unpaid housework, driven by technological changes in household management.

design.sample_characteristics: The study focuses on Canadian domestic servants, primarily women, during the late 19th and early 20th centuries.

dependent_variables.displaced: The decline of domestic service as a paid occupation.
dependent_variables.unemployment_or_underemployment: High turnover rates and short duration of employment in domestic service.
dependent_variables.duration: Short duration of employment in domestic service.
dependent_variables.wage_changes: Domestic servants' wages did not keep pace with other occupations, leading to a decline in the occupation.

text_fragments: 'I'd rather pick rags and keep my self-respect!' Such was the reaction of one Canadian woman who faced the prospect of becoming a domestic servant in the early twentieth century.
qualitative_data.narrative_descriptions: The study describes the transformation of domestic service from a paid occupation to unpaid housework, influenced by technological changes and shifts in labor supply and demand.

historical_context.economic_conditions: The study covers a period of economic transformation in Canada, with shifts in labor supply and demand affecting domestic service.
historical_context.institutional_context: The study discusses labor market conditions, immigration policies, and societal attitudes towards domestic service.

outcomes.main_findings: Domestic service declined as a paid occupation due to technological changes and shifts in labor supply and demand. The occupation was replaced by unpaid housework performed by housewives.
outcomes.conclusions: The decline of domestic service was not solely due to economic factors but also involved changes in societal attitudes and technological advancements.
outcomes.long_term_impacts: The decline of paid domestic service led to the devaluation of housework and increased unpaid labor for women.
